iana.encoding_considerations:
Security considerations: Apache Parquet can be used to store arbitrary data which may or may not be sensitive in nature. Executable content is not expected. Apache Parquet supports multiple compression codecs and a single file may contain uncompressed and compressed regions. Apache Parquet files may be encrypted using mechanisms suitable for other file formats or using the format's modular encryption mechanism, whereby a file may contain both unencrypted and encrypted data regions.

Interoperability considerations: Apache Parquet is designed to be highly-interoperable and can be read and written using software libraries and applications written in a wide variety of programming languages running on many platforms. The format is versioned and developed in a backwards-compatible fashion. Users can generally expect Apache Parquet files created by one system to be read in correctly by another system.

Published specification: https://parquet.apache.org/docs/file-format

Applications which use this media: The Parquet file format is an efficient, general-purpose, column-oriented data format used across a wide variety of platforms, technologies, and environments.

Fragment identifier considerations: N/A

Restrictions on usage: None

iana.template_text:
(registered 2024-02-14, last updated 2024-03-05)

Media type name: application

Media subtype name: vnd.apache.parquet

Required parameters: N/A

Optional parameters: N/A

Encoding considerations: binary

Security considerations: Apache Parquet can be used to store arbitrary data which may or may not be sensitive in nature. Executable content is not expected. Apache Parquet supports multiple compression codecs and a single file may contain uncompressed and compressed regions. Apache Parquet files may be encrypted using mechanisms suitable for other file formats or using the format's modular encryption mechanism, whereby a file may contain both unencrypted and encrypted data regions.

Interoperability considerations: Apache Parquet is designed to be highly-interoperable and can be read and written using software libraries and applications written in a wide variety of programming languages running on many platforms. The format is versioned and developed in a backwards-compatible fashion. Users can generally expect Apache Parquet files created by one system to be read in correctly by another system.

Published specification: https://parquet.apache.org/docs/file-format

Applications which use this media: The Parquet file format is an efficient, general-purpose, column-oriented data format used across a wide variety of platforms, technologies, and environments.

Fragment identifier considerations: N/A

Restrictions on usage: None

Additional information:

1. Deprecated alias names for this type: x-parquet
2. Magic number(s): PAR1, PARE
3. File extension(s): .parquet
4. Macintosh file type code: not available
5. Object Identifiers: not available

General Comments:

Person to contact for further information:

1. Name: Apache Parquet Project Management Committee
2. Email: private&parquet.apache.org

Intended usage: COMMON
